message_content:
The study primarily explores how rural residents think about smog (its severity and causes), what they say they would do when confronted with polluting activities (intervention vs silence), and their satisfaction with government smog‐control efforts. This corresponds to:
- Perceptions (awareness, perceived severity, beliefs about causes)
- Behaviors (stated willingness—or unwillingness—to intervene)
- Policy (attitudes toward government performance in smog control)

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy"]}

The paper is fundamentally about how people think and feel about air pollution—specifically their awareness, perceived risks, opinions, and knowledge. It explicitly examines public perception of air pollution and its health risks. While it discusses implications for environmental public policy, it does not present survey data on policy preferences or concrete behaviors. Therefore, it best fits into:

• Perceptions – it centers on what people know and believe about air pollution.  
• Health – it focuses on perceptions of health risks from air pollution.

output_json

{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper examines survey respondents’ attitudes and knowledge about air pollution (e.g., concern, familiarity, recognition of high pollution, beliefs about overregulation), their self-reported behaviors related to pollution exposure, and their opinions on government regulation of pollution. Therefore it falls into:

- Perceptions: it measures concern, beliefs, and knowledge about air pollution  
- Behaviors: it reports self-reported actions/behaviors concerning air pollution  
- Policy: it assesses opinions about government regulation of pollution  

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy"]}

The paper measures both the health impacts of air pollution (lost workdays, treatment costs) and households’ expressed intentions to act (willingness to pay) specifically for programs providing cleaner air—which is a policy preference. Hence it spans:

- Health: quantifying health-related impacts via lost workdays and medical costs  
- Behaviors: capturing stated willingness to act (willingness to pay)  
- Policy: evaluating preferences for institutional programs to improve air quality  

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Health", "Behaviors", "Policy"]
}

The study surveys respondents on their perceptions of air quality improvement and health improvements related to pollution changes, without assessing any concrete behaviors or policy preferences. It therefore falls into:
- Perceptions: captures what people think and believe about air pollution (improvement and sources).  
- Health: includes survey-based perceptions of health impacts due to air quality changes.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The study uses parents’ perceptions of indoor air odors and humidity as indicators of pollutant exposure and then links those perceptions to child health outcomes (asthma, wheeze, cough, rhinitis). Thus, it involves:  
- Perceptions (parents’ perceived odors and air quality)  
- Health (survey data on children’s allergic and respiratory health linked to perceived air quality)

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper examines how people’s perceived susceptibility and severity of PM2.5 (risk perceptions) drive their negative affect and in turn their intentions to adopt protective behaviors (behavioral intentions). It also directly measures health risk perceptions related to air pollution. Therefore, it spans:

- Perceptions: It measures perceived susceptibility and severity of PM2.5.
- Behaviors: It assesses intentions to adopt protective measures.
- Health: It focuses on health-related risk perceptions and protective health behaviors.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]
}

The paper uses contingent valuation (willingness-to-pay) to value improvements in air quality (i.e., a stated preference for policy action) and analyzes health diaries to quantify minor respiratory illness and related cost impacts. Thus, it covers both:  
- Policy (willingness-to-pay for air quality improvements)  
- Health (survey-based assessment of respiratory symptoms and associated costs)

output_json
{"categories": ["Policy", "Health"]}

The study investigates Beijing residents’ intentions to take protective actions (wearing facemasks, using air purifiers) in response to smog, and it measures key belief constructs (perceived threat, benefits, barriers, self-efficacy). Thus, it clearly falls into:
- Behaviors (focus on what people intend to do)  
- Perceptions (focus on what people believe about smog risks and benefits of protective measures)  

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors"]}

The paper develops and validates a questionnaire to assess runners’ beliefs and perceptions of health risks from air pollution (e.g., perceived susceptibility, severity, benefits, barriers, self‐efficacy) and also measures their health‐protective intentions in response to pollution.  
- It squarely addresses how people think about and perceive air pollution risks (Perceptions).  
- It includes measures of intended protective actions (Behaviors).  
- It is framed within health impacts and health behavior theory (Health).  

output_json

{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]
}

The study develops and validates a questionnaire assessing runners’ perceptions of air pollution risks (e.g., perceived susceptibility, severity, and awareness), their health‐related beliefs and intentions to act (e.g., health behavior intention, perceived benefits/barriers), and explicitly connects these to health outcomes via the Health Belief Model. Therefore, it covers:
- Perceptions: measures what runners think and believe about air pollution risks.
- Behaviors: includes runners’ stated intentions to take protective actions.
- Health: focuses on health-related perceptions and behaviors in relation to pollution exposure.

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]}

The paper examines how individuals’ perceptions of air pollution shape their evaluations of central government environmental performance, explicitly exploring subjective perceptions and attitudes toward government action on pollution. Thus, it falls under:
- Perceptions: it analyzes what people think and perceive about air pollution.
- Policy: it assesses public attitudes toward government environmental governance efforts.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy"]
}

The paper examines students’ perceptions of indoor air quality (PAQ), their reported occupant behaviors (e.g., use of air fresheners, ventilation habits), and the health-related outcomes (SBS symptoms) associated with these factors. Therefore, it fits into:
- Perceptions: it assesses perceived air quality.
- Behaviors: it analyzes actual occupant behaviors affecting IAQ.
- Health: it links air quality to sick building syndrome symptoms.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]
}

The study assesses how variations in ventilation affect participants’ perceptions of indoor air quality (PAQ) and self-reported Sick Building Syndrome (SBS) health symptoms. It does not examine behaviors people take in response to pollution, policy preferences, or the relative priority of air pollution issues. Therefore, it falls into:

- Perceptions: It measures participants’ perceived air quality.  
- Health: It collects self-reported health symptoms (SBS) linked to indoor air pollution.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper elicits residents’ knowledge, concerns, and perceptions about industrial air pollution impacts, including explicit references to community health risks. It does not investigate actual or intended mitigation behaviors, nor does it assess support for specific policies or ranking of air pollution relative to other issues. Therefore, it falls under:
- Perceptions (residents’ beliefs and concerns about air pollution)
- Health (perceptions of health impacts from air pollution)

output_json
{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The study uses Q-methodology to capture experts’ beliefs and opinions about particulate matter reduction effects of urban green spaces and discusses implications for policy design and construction. Thus, it falls under:
- Perceptions: It assesses what experts think and believe about PM reduction by green spaces.
- Policy: It seeks to inform and establish guidelines and policies for integrating green spaces to reduce particulate matter.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy"]
}

The study investigates not only respondents’ awareness and beliefs about air pollution (public perception of causes and satisfaction with current control) but also their expressed willingness to act—specifically willingness to pay—and preferences for government measures. Therefore, it spans:

- Perceptions: it measures awareness of pollution and satisfaction with existing controls.  
- Behaviors: it assesses stated willingness to participate in pollution treatment.  
- Policy: it evaluates willingness to pay for air‐pollution treatment policies.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy"]
}

The paper assesses what people know and believe about air pollution (knowledge of sources, beliefs about health impacts), examines their reported practices to reduce exposure, and explicitly connects perceptions to cardiopulmonary health outcomes. Therefore, it falls under:

- Perceptions: knowledge and attitudes about air pollution and its sources  
- Behaviors: reported practices to lower exposure  
- Health: perceptions of and attitudes toward the health impacts of air pollution  

output_json

{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]
}

The study elicits respondents’ willingness to pay for haze governance (an intended action/behavior and a policy preference) and also measures their haze knowledge and concern (perceptions). It thus spans:

- Policy: it assesses support for pollution-reduction funding and beliefs about responsibility.  
- Behaviors: willingness to pay is a stated behavioral intention.  
- Perceptions: haze knowledge and concern reflect what people know and believe about air pollution.

output_json
{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy"]
}

This study uses survey data to assess  
- residents’ perceptions of air pollution-related nuisance (odors) and satisfaction levels (Perceptions),  
- self-reported health risks and symptoms linked to pollution exposure (Health),  
- and even measures their stated willingness to change living locations in response to pollution (Behaviors).  

output_json

{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health", "Behaviors"]
}

The paper focuses on residents’ perceptions of odour nuisance, health risks, satisfaction with their health and the landfill/quarry operations—all measured via Likert scales—as well as self-reported health impacts; it also records respondents’ stated willingness to change their living location in response to pollution. Therefore, it spans:

- Perceptions (what people think and feel about pollution and its effects)  
- Health (self-reported health risks and perceptions of health impacts)  
- Behaviors (stated willingness to relocate as a concrete response to pollution)  

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Health", "Behaviors"]}

This paper examines how individuals’ perceptions of air and noise pollution (visual air pollution, olfactory air pollution, and noise) relate to self-perceived health, happiness, and life satisfaction. It therefore falls into:
- Perceptions: it directly measures what people think and feel about pollution.
- Health: it links those perceptions to self-reported health and well-being outcomes.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper examines residents’ perceptions of exposure risks (risk perception), their intended protective actions (self-protective willingness), their willingness to pay/support a stove renovation policy, and quantifies health impacts via PM2.5 exposure and excess mortality risk. Thus it spans:
- Perceptions (risk perception of air pollution),
- Behaviors (willingness to take protective actions),
- Policy (willingness to pay/support stove renovation policy),
- Health (PM2.5 exposure and health risk assessment).

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy", "Health"]
}

The paper examines how individuals’ perceptions of air pollution influence their evaluation of government environmental governance (i.e., satisfaction with policies), without focusing on actual behaviors, health impacts, or issue prioritization. Therefore, it falls under:
- Perceptions (people’s beliefs about air pollution)
- Policy (evaluation of government environmental governance)

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy"]}

The study reports on women’s actual cooking practices (fuel choice, location, meal frequency), their awareness and beliefs about HAP health risks and improved cookstoves, and their preferences for stove features. Thus it covers:
- Behaviors (reported cooking activities in relation to air pollution),
- Perceptions (awareness and beliefs about HAP and ICS),
- Health (perceptions of HAP-related health risks).

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Behaviors", "Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper examines how non-experts interpret verbal probability expressions and assesses their subjective perceptions of health risks from ambient air pollution. This clearly falls under:
- Perceptions: it studies what people think and believe about air pollution risk (verbal-numeric probability mappings).
- Health: it specifically measures perceptions of health risks associated with pollution.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

This paper develops and tests a model of “adaptive behaviour” toward air pollution, explicitly measuring both people’s risk perceptions (perceived vulnerability, perceived severity, response efficacy, self-efficacy) and their adaptive actions (behavioural intentions/actions). Therefore, it covers both:
- Perceptions (risk perception, attitudes, vulnerability/severity beliefs)
- Behaviors (adaptive actions or intentions in response to air pollution)

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors"]
}

The paper centers on how different policy measures influence residents’ intentions and actual PM2.5 reduction behaviors (i.e., what people are willing to do and report doing) and evaluates the effectiveness of those specific government‐led policies. Therefore, it falls under:

- Behaviors: because it examines residents’ intended and actual PM2.5 reduction actions.
- Policy: because it models and compares different policy interventions and their impacts.

output_json
{"categories": ["Behaviors", "Policy"]}

The paper develops and simulates how different policy measures (command-and-control, economic incentives, education) affect residents’ intentions and actual PM2.5 reduction behaviors. It therefore centers on:  
- Behaviors: examining stated intentions and reported reduction actions.  
- Policy: evaluating the effectiveness of various government interventions on those behaviors.

output_json
{
  "categories": ["Behaviors", "Policy"]
}

The paper uses an online questionnaire to capture occupants’ perceptions of indoor air quality and self-reported health symptoms in a school setting. It does not assess any behaviors taken in response to air pollution, evaluate policy preferences, nor rank air pollution against other priorities. Therefore, it falls under:

- Perceptions: It measures how pupils and teachers perceive indoor air quality.  
- Health: It records self‐reported health symptoms related to indoor air quality.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper surveys employees’ perceptions of indoor air quality (e.g., reports of stuffy or dry air, insufficient ventilation) and also collects self‐reported symptoms (health indicators) linked to that perceived air quality. It does not address behaviors, policy preferences, or priority rankings. Thus it falls under:
- Perceptions: examining how people perceive their indoor air environment  
- Health: using survey data to identify self‐reported health impacts of air quality

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The study examines both what people think (their evaluation of indoor air quality and perceptions of health risks) and what they do (application to a stove-replacement programme, i.e. adoption of pellet stoves). It also links air pollution to respiratory health impairments and perceived severity of health effects. Hence it covers:

• Perceptions – assessing indoor air quality evaluations and risk perceptions  
• Behaviors – analyzing actual participation in the stove‐replacement programme  
• Health – relating respiratory impairments and perceived health impacts of pollution

output_json

{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]
}

The study surveys adolescents’ beliefs about the seriousness of air pollution and the health risks (e.g., respiratory effects, death) they associate with it. It does not examine their protective behaviors, policy preferences, or rank pollution against other issues. Therefore, it falls under:

- Perceptions: because it captures what students think and believe about air pollution’s severity and risks.
- Health: because it specifically measures perceptions of health-related impacts from air pollution.

output_json

{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper assesses what adolescents think about air pollution—how serious they consider it and what health risks they associate with it. It therefore fits into:
- Perceptions: it explores students’ awareness and beliefs about air pollution levels and associated risks.
- Health: it specifically examines perceived health risks of air pollution in a survey context.

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]}

The paper surveys occupants’ perceptions of indoor air quality and comfort, and reports self‐reported health symptoms attributed to the building environment (e.g. headaches, dry eyes, sore throat). Thus, it clearly falls under:

- Perceptions: It measures how people perceive indoor air quality and related comfort factors.
- Health: It reports self‐reported health symptoms linked to the building’s air quality.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The study clearly explores multiple dimensions of how people relate to air pollution in Beirut:

1. Perceptions: It measures respondents’ awareness of air pollution, their beliefs about its seriousness, and their knowledge of its sources and health impacts.  
2. Behaviors: It documents whether people reported taking actions to reduce exposure to or emissions of air pollution (in this case, no one reported such actions).  
3. Policy: It assesses respondents’ awareness of existing environmental policies/strategies and their trust in decision makers and experts regarding air pollution.  
4. Health: It focuses on perceived health risks from air pollution, including specific diseases people associate with pollution.  
5. Priority: It asks respondents to rank air pollution among environmental issues, finding it perceived as the most serious risk.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy", "Health", "Priority"]
}

The paper surveys building stakeholders about what they think they currently experience (their perceptions of indoor air quality and its benefits/costs), asks how much they would be willing to pay (a stated behavior), and probes their beliefs about health impacts. Therefore it spans:
- Perceptions (what people think or believe about IAQ)  
- Behaviors (stated willingness to pay for IAQ improvements)  
- Health (perceptions of health impacts due to IAQ)  

output_json

{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]
}

The paper examines adults’ perceptions of health risks from air pollution during their commute and assesses whether pollution is seen as a barrier to walking or cycling (a perceived barrier rather than actual behavior). It thus clearly falls under:
- Perceptions: it focuses on what people think and believe about air pollution exposure and risks.
- Health: it centers on perceived health impacts of air pollution.

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]}

The paper examines how public participation influences subjective evaluation of smog-governing policies and explores respondents’ concern (perception) about air quality and their expected subsidy (policy preference/willingness to pay). Therefore, it clearly falls into:

- Policy: because it evaluates public attitudes and preferences toward government smog policies, using ordered probit and IV models.  
- Perceptions: because it measures respondents’ concern and perception of air quality.

output_json

{
    "categories": ["Policy", "Perceptions"]
}

The paper primarily explores how people perceive indoor air quality and associate it with health symptoms, and it captures self-reported concerns about health impacts. Therefore, it falls into:

- Perceptions: examines awareness, perceived risks, and beliefs about indoor air pollution.  
- Health: identifies perceived health-related impacts and concerns linked to air pollution.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}

The paper assesses public knowledge and perceptions of smog (including health risk perceptions), and examines how these perceptions relate to attitudes and the intention to reduce private car use. Thus, it spans:  
- Perceptions (smog knowledge and risk perceptions)  
- Behaviors (intention to reduce car use)  
- Health (physical and mental health risk perceptions)  

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Health"]}

The paper examines how people perceive the health risks of PM2.5 (risk perception), measures their willingness to pay/accept monetary compensation for pollution reduction (a stated preference for policy action), and explicitly links these attitudes to health impacts. Therefore it spans:

- Perceptions: it measures respondents’ perceived effects of haze pollution and risk acceptance levels  
- Policy: it uses contingent valuation to assess willingness to pay/accept for emission controls  
- Health: it focuses on perceived health risks of air pollution and aims to inform protective measures  

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy", "Health"]
}

The study primarily examines how residents perceive and react to the government’s red warnings (their beliefs about timing, duration, and necessity) and elicits their preferences for different emergency measures (school closings versus air purifiers, driving restrictions versus road flushing). These fall under:

- Perceptions: It captures what people think or believe about the warnings and their adequacy.  
- Policy: It elicits public attitudes and preferences toward specific air‐pollution control policies and emergency measures.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy"]
}

The study primarily assesses what people think and know about air pollution (their awareness of air quality changes and pollution sources), how they view government action on environmental protection (support for increased funding and prioritization), and how strongly they believe the issue should be addressed (urgency and priority). Thus, it covers:

- Perceptions (awareness and beliefs about air quality and pollution sources)  
- Policy (opinions on government spending and actions to control air pollution)  
- Priority (the urgency respondents assign to environmental protection and air quality)

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy", "Priority"]
}

The paper measures how people think about haze pollution (risk perception), what they are willing to do (pay for masks and purifiers), and their support for institutional actions (willingness to pay for haze management). Therefore, it falls into:

- Perceptions (risk perception of haze)
- Behaviors (willingness to pay as an intended protective action)
- Policy (willingness to pay for local authority–led haze management)

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy"]
}

I classify this paper in the following categories:

Explanation:
The title “Survey of Residents’ Perceptions and Concerns on Air Pollution in Maharashtra, India” indicates that the study uses survey data to capture what people think and believe about air pollution (Perceptions). The inclusion of “Concerns” suggests that the paper also assesses how important or urgent respondents find the issue, which aligns with Priority.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Priority"]
}

The paper primarily assesses students’ knowledge and beliefs about air pollution (composition, consequences) and their attitudes toward measures to reduce it—particularly their relative acceptability of financial penalties versus legal compulsion. This maps onto:

- Perceptions: it explores what students know and believe about air pollution (sources, nature, consequences).
- Policy: it examines students’ attitudes toward specific policy instruments (financial penalties vs legal compulsion).

output_json
{
  "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy"]
}

The study examines both what people think (risk perceptions, knowledge, emotions, trust in government) and what they intend to do or actually do (protective actions against particulate matter), and additionally evaluates attitudes toward government competency, policy awareness, and satisfaction with PM-related policies. Therefore, it spans:
- Perceptions (risk perception, knowledge, emotions, trust)  
- Behaviors (intention and actual protective actions)  
- Policy (attitudes toward government factors, policy satisfaction and awareness)

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Policy"]}

I classify this paper under Perceptions, Behaviors, and Priority:

- Perceptions: It measures how respondents think about and use information on city air quality when assessing tourist attractiveness.  
- Behaviors: It examines how this information influences their intended travel decisions (choice of destination).  
- Priority: It assesses the importance respondents assign to air quality relative to other factors when planning a trip.  

output_json
{"categories": ["Perceptions", "Behaviors", "Priority"]}

This study investigates how people perceive the health risks of air pollution (public awareness of risk), their confidence in government strategies to address it (attitudes toward policy), and links these perceptions to self-reported health status. Therefore, it covers:
- Perceptions: assessing awareness and beliefs about air pollution risks.
- Policy: examining confidence in government measures for air pollution.
- Health: relating air pollution risk awareness to personal health status.

output_json
{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Policy", "Health"]
}

The paper’s survey component focuses on community awareness and beliefs about how the MSW facility affects air quality and health, rather than on what actions people take, support for specific policies, or how air pollution ranks among other issues. It also explicitly addresses perceived impacts on well‐being and health. Therefore, it falls into:

- Perceptions (awareness and beliefs about air pollution)  
- Health (perceived or self‐reported health impacts)  

output_json

{
    "categories": ["Perceptions", "Health"]
}
